summary:
Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Paul Merson, a Sky Sports pundit, has reignited his feud with Tottenham midfielder Andros Townsend. Merson had previously questioned Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, but was proven wrong when Townsend scored a stunning equaliser for England against Italy. Although Merson admitted his mistake and congratulated Townsend, he has since taken another dig at him on Twitter after Townsend was brought on for only 7 minutes in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. This is not the first time the two have exchanged words on Twitter, with Townsend having previously responded to Merson's criticism after scoring for England.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Chelsea has made an offer to sign 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto. If the deal is completed, Muto will join Chelsea's partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan next season. The offer is reportedly not related to Chelsea's £200million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. Muto, a Japan international with 11 caps, has not yet decided whether to join Chelsea, but considers the offer an "honour". A £4million deal has been mooted, and if completed, Muto would become the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The study, which compared the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds, found that children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight, with boys being more prone to weight gain. Repeated prescriptions before the age of two also raised the odds of being overweight. The researchers suggest that antibiotics may be contributing to the obesity epidemic by killing off gut bugs that normally feed on food, freeing up more food for the body and potentially increasing appetite. The study's lead author warns of the importance of judicious use of antibiotics in infancy, citing the potential role of antibiotics in the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident was caught on camera by a tourist, David Meadwell, who was recording the event. The guard lost his footing, slid sideways, and dropped his rifle, before quickly scrambling to his feet. The fall is believed to have been caused by the metal protectors on the soles of his boots. Despite the embarrassing moment, the guard's colleagues marched past as if nothing had happened. The incident occurred during a popular tourist event, where thousands gather to watch the changing of the guard outside Buckingham Palace.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

The 1977 miniseries "Roots" is being remade by A&E networks to air in 2016. The new version will be a simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History, and will draw more from Alex Haley's novel. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake. The producers aim to add authenticity by consulting scholars in African and African-American history. The remake aims to introduce the story to a new generation, while also resonating with fans of the original, amidst a contemporary context of ongoing racial issues in the US.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, 64, has alleged that palace aides at Clarence House tried to force him into an orgy in 1978. He claims he was pinned to a chair, groped, and threatened after refusing to participate. Lawler reported the incident to palace officials at the time, but his complaint was ignored. He contacted the palace again last year after learning of investigations into historical child sex abuse cases, but his complaint was initially rebuffed. The complaint was eventually passed to Scotland Yard, and a retired royal aide was interviewed, denying involvement. The Royal Household has stated it will cooperate with the police investigation, which is ongoing.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song of 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'. The video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood. They reveal that they spent two months trying to conceive and were surprised by the news. The video was made to share the news with loved ones living far away, but it unexpectedly went viral. The couple has shared a sonogram of their unborn child at the end of the video and may create another video after finding out the child's gender.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt, which featured a black zigzag applique, was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film auctioned by Heritage Auctions. The dress was worn in several key scenes, including when Scarlett meets Rhett Butler and is attacked in the shanty town. The outfit has faded from its original slate blue-gray color to light gray due to age. The auction was part of a private collection amassed by James Tumblin, who collected over 300,000 pieces of memorabilia from the film. Other notable items sold at the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), a suit worn by Clark Gable ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000).

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A 2-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The boy slipped from his mother's grasp and fell 10-12ft into the pit, but was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived. He suffered minor bumps and bruises, including a leg injury, and is in stable condition at the hospital. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family, citing eyewitness accounts that suggest the child was deliberately dangled over the railing. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which has been non-operational for over 2 years, has been re-angled to point at a house's front door. The camera was one of around 300 speed and traffic cameras turned off in the West Midlands in 2013 due to obsolete technology. The city council is aware of the issue and will take action, potentially removing the camera, as it is not part of a new pilot program using digital technology.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete for Jamaica at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2-3. Bolt has confirmed his participation, stating he is fit and ready to run. He aims to make Jamaica proud, following the country's successful tradition in relays. The full Jamaican team list will be announced shortly, with JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle expressing excitement about Bolt's availability for selection.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Neymar and Dani Alves, Barcelona team-mates, showed their support for the club's basketball side by attending an El Clasico Euro League match, which Barcelona won 85-80. Despite the win, Real Madrid remain top of their division due to points difference. Meanwhile, Neymar had recently helped Brazil beat Chile 1-0 in a football match at the Emirates Stadium. Barcelona, led by Luis Enrique, are currently four points clear at the top of La Liga and will resume their campaign against Celta Vigo on Sunday, competing for a treble of trophies.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

* A large number of migrants from Africa and the Middle East are attempting to reach Europe, with 8,480 rescued by the Italian coast guard from Friday to Monday.
* There are concerns that 400 migrants may be missing after a ship carrying 550 people reportedly capsized off the Libyan coast, although the Italian coast guard has not found evidence to confirm this incident.
* The Mediterranean Sea has seen a recent surge in migrant boats, with over 10,000 migrants arriving in Italy in the first three months of 2015, and at least 480 deaths reported since the beginning of the year, often due to bad weather and overcrowding.
* Most migrants are from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, and use Libya as a transit country, with many facing dangerous conditions and abandonment by smugglers.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, despite not knowing the exact reason for the decision. Sanchez has made a significant impact, scoring 19 goals so far this season. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez may have been used as leverage in negotiations for Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. The Arsenal boss praises Sanchez's adaptability and qualities, considering him one of the best players around. Ahead of the upcoming match against Liverpool, Wenger plays down speculation about a potential transfer move for Raheem Sterling and expresses admiration for Liverpool's development under Brendan Rodgers despite the loss of Suarez and injury to Daniel Sturridge.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion, will attempt to break the cycling hour record on June 7 at the London Olympic Velodrome. The current record is 52.491km, set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins, who will turn 35 on April 28, aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes and is expected to set a mark that will last for some time. The event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports and tickets will go on sale from April 19, with prices ranging from £29 to £49. Wiggins' attempt is part of his return to the track, as he targets a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Serena Williams, the world No 1, struggled to beat Sara Errani 4-6 7-6(3) 6-3 in the Fed Cup, describing the match as a "big eye-opener" that showed she is not ready for the claycourt season. Despite winning, the US team was beaten 3-2 and relegated to World Group II after losing the doubles rubber. Williams acknowledged that she needs to adapt her playing style to clay courts, and US captain Mary Joe Fernandez stated that the team needs to work harder to get back into the World Group next year.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

River Plate are interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the Argentine club from 2001 to 2009. Vice president Matias Patanian stated that the club "dream of Falcao" and the doors are open for his return. Falcao has struggled at Manchester United, scoring only 4 Premier League goals, but has recently found form for Colombia, scoring 3 goals in 2 games. A deal to bring him back to River Plate is considered complicated, with his future uncertain as Manchester United decide whether to keep him or return him to parent club Monaco.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old X Factor finalist and pop star, has partnered with dry shampoo brand Batiste as the face of their 2015 'Ready For It' campaign. This is her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson in various hairstyles, showcasing the product, and is accompanied by a TV advertising campaign featuring her single "Mirror Man". Henderson expressed excitement about working with the brand, citing it as a product she uses regularly. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency and marks a significant endorsement for the young artist.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres, who shot and killed 26-year-old Aaron Siler on March 14, has been erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, thanks the community for its support. Siler's family and friends are outraged, calling the billboard "disrespectful" and asking for it to be taken down. Officer Torres is currently on leave pending the outcome of the investigation into Siler's death. The police association claims no offense was intended, but Siler's family and friends feel the billboard is insensitive, especially given that Torres had also shot another man, Terry Knight, just 10 days prior to Siler's death. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing, while the investigation into Knight's shooting was determined to be justified.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border. The militants, from the group Jaish al Adal, crossed into Iran from Pakistan and three of them were killed by Iranian forces. Iranian officials have asked Pakistan to catch the surviving assailants, and Pakistan has condemned the attack and promised to investigate and apprehend any militants who may have fled into their territory. Jaish al Adal is an anti-Iranian group that has targeted Shiites and aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan, and has claimed responsibility for previous attacks on Iranian territory.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

The Japanese government's top military official, Defense Minister Gen Nakatani, revealed that the country's Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial unidentified flying object (UFO). This statement was made in response to a query from lawmaker Antonio Inoki, who asked if aircraft were ever scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats and if research was being done into alien visitors. Nakatani explained that while the ASDF has detected and investigated unidentified flying objects, they have always been found to be of earthly origin, such as birds or other aircraft. Inoki, who claims to have seen a UFO himself, prompted the discussion, which is not the first time Japanese politicians have considered the implications of extraterrestrial visitors, with a previous defense minister discussing the legal ramifications of defending against an alien invasion in 2007.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after a toilet he was squatting on in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport broke, causing him to fall and shatter the porcelain. He had been trying to avoid touching the seat due to cleanliness concerns. The incident occurred when the toilet tipped over and cut him in several places. Jin Pai received dozens of stitches and later changed his story to police, claiming he was sitting when the toilet broke, possibly to avoid compensation. Authorities believe the incident was an accident and are reminding people to use toilets for sitting, not standing.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Kevin Rebbie, 56, of Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for allegedly sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl and filming her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom over a 4-year period. The girl found the camera in March and reported that Rebbie had been watching her since she was 9 years old and had molested her while she was sleeping. Investigators found 41 videos, including footage of the girl and others showering, which Rebbie had uploaded to his computer. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy, and is being held on $500,000 bail with a preliminary hearing set for May 1.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of images featuring fathers leaping into the air next to their daughters. The photos, part of a book called "Daughter and Salary Man", show the daughters looking directly at the camera with a smile, while their fathers, dressed in sharp suits, pull dramatic poses. The images, taken in front of Japanese landmarks, aim to showcase the fathers' fun side, with some adopting pained expressions due to their age. The series has generated interest online due to its unique and curious nature.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

The dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director has potentially paved the way for Kevin Pietersen's return to the England team. Pietersen, 34, was axed by Downton in 2014, but with Downton's sacking, Pietersen may be able to force his way back into the Test set-up. Pietersen has rejoined Surrey and is preparing for the county championship season, which starts on April 19. He was seen in a jovial mood during a Surrey team photo shoot, but also appeared deep in thought, suggesting he is focused on his goal of returning to the England team, particularly with the Ashes series approaching this summer.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club, has sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week due to a poor run of results, including a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. Ze Maria had been reinstated after initially being fired, but the latest loss led to his permanent dismissal. He will be replaced by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic, with the club currently 16th in the standings and six points from safety.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Radamel Falcao's former team-mate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao regrets his loan move to Manchester United, despite being unhappy at Monaco. Falcao has struggled at United, scoring only 4 goals, and the club is unlikely to make his transfer permanent due to the £46million price tag. Dirar thinks Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he would have played in the Champions League, even though he wasn't happy there.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday, making off with the till and approximately $1500 in cash. The tall offender demanded cash from the owner's daughter, threw the cash register to the ground, and fled the scene. Police are seeking public help to identify the man and are asking anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message police online.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, has been arrested twice for having inappropriate relationships with 15-year-old students. The first arrest occurred on March 19, after she admitted to kissing a student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April of the previous year. She was released on bail and suspended from teaching. However, a second student came forward, accusing Granado of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January. She was arrested again on Monday and released after posting a $50,000 bail. Granado is currently on administrative leave, preventing her from working with students or being present on school property.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A video of a crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog in its jaws, has been viewed over 500,000 times. The incident occurred when the dog, belonging to a local bike shop owner, approached the water's edge and was attacked by the crocodile. The crocodile, which is common in the area due to the nearby mangroves and sanctuary, held onto the dog for hours, shocking tourists, including New Zealander Tim Weston, who witnessed the event. The video has sparked horror and negative reactions towards crocodiles on social media.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Hull City, managed by Steve Bruce, is battling to stay in the Premier League after a 2-0 defeat to Southampton. Despite a strong start, Hull has only managed 6 wins and is just 2 points clear of the drop zone with 6 games left to play, including tough fixtures against top teams. Bruce remains confident that his team can avoid relegation, citing the return of injured players and the team's positive attitude. He attributes their struggles to long-term injuries to key players, but believes they have enough to stay out of trouble. Meanwhile, Southampton's win moved them up to fifth in the table, but manager Ronald Koeman has disciplinary issues to address after a penalty dispute between James Ward-Prowse and Sadio Mane.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Ian Guffick, a 31-year-old teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Gloucestershire, has been banned from the classroom for at least two years after allowing pupils to change their SATs exam answers and altering some himself. The incident led to the Department for Education annulling the entire school's SATs results for 2014. Guffick admitted to unacceptable professional conduct, but claimed he only asked pupils to make their answers more legible. The National College for Teaching and Leadership found his actions to be dishonest, but not fraudulent. Guffick has shown remorse and regrets his actions, which had a serious impact on the school. He has 28 days to appeal the decision to the High Court.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Anders Lindegaard, the Manchester United goalkeeper, is enjoying life off the pitch with his wife, Swedish model Misse Beqiri, whom he married in 2014 in Mauritius. The couple has a son together and have been dating since 2012. Despite struggling for playing time at Manchester United, making only 19 league appearances in five seasons, Lindegaard is happy in his personal life, often sharing moments with his wife on social media. He is currently third-choice goalkeeper at Old Trafford and has been told he can leave the club, with a potential move to FC Midtjylland having fallen through in January.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

The iconic 13 glowing blue letters that hung above Yankee Stadium from 1976 to 2008 failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, with an expected price of $300,000 to $600,000. The current owner, Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, who purchased the letters after the stadium's final game in 2008, was hoping to pass them on to a new generation. Despite no bids being placed, a Sotheby's employee made a starting bid of $260,000, but it was not enough to sell the letters. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 1960s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has spoken to Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities after they were pictured inhaling nitrous oxide and smoking shisha pipes. Neither player will be disciplined, and Rodgers wants to move on from the incident. The team is preparing for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, with Steven Gerrard available after a three-match suspension. Rodgers is focused on reaching his first FA Cup final as Liverpool manager, and believes the team is ready to progress after falling short in previous competitions.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, has returned to London after the international break, where he helped Germany win 2-0 against Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. He posted a picture on Twitter relaxing with his dog, indicating he is enjoying his downtime. Ozil, who missed Arsenal's last game due to illness, is expected to start against Liverpool at the weekend. He has been in fine form since returning from injury, with 4 assists and 3 goals since January, and feels he has adjusted to English football, citing the busy schedule as a good fit for his playing style.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Barcelona president Josep Maria Bartomeu has expressed his satisfaction with manager Luis Enrique, stating that the club has no plans to replace him. Despite speculation, Bartomeu is impressed with Enrique's performance, citing the team's potential to win three trophies this season. Enrique, who took charge last summer, has a contract until 2016 and is focused on the remaining games, including the Champions League. The team recently defeated Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi, demonstrating their strong form.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has agreed to a new long-term contract with the club, worth around £100,000 per week, which will run until 2020. This comes after 14 months of negotiations and provides a lift for the club following their FA Cup semi-final defeat. Henderson, 24, is the third key player to sign a contract extension, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. He is expected to be considered for the role of club captain when Steven Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy this summer.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Filipe Luis, Chelsea's full back, wants to stay at the club until the end of his 3-year contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. Luis has struggled to establish himself at Chelsea, but is committed to the club. With the Premier League title run-in approaching, manager Jose Mourinho is keeping the team focused, and Luis believes they are prepared for the challenging final 9 games.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Nathan Hughes, a Wasps player, had his 3-match ban overturned on appeal after accidentally knocking out George North with his knee while scoring a try for Northampton on March 27. The initial disciplinary panel ruled Hughes was "reckless" and gave him a ban, but the appeal panel found that the incident occurred accidentally and no act of foul play took place. As a result, Hughes' red card has been rescinded and he is free to return to action immediately. George North, who suffered his third concussion in two months, has been advised to take at least a month off from playing to recover. The decision to overturn the ban was met with support from many in the rugby community, who felt that the initial ban was unjustified.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Raging wildfires in southeastern Siberia, started by farmers burning grass, spread out of control due to strong winds and destroyed dozens of villages. The resulting smoke was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, affecting parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, causing intense red sunsets, especially during sunrise and sunset when light travels through more atmosphere. As the smoke dissipates, air quality will improve and the reddish hue of the sunsets will fade.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

Becky Schoenig, a Missouri mom, had her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway. However, the car was found and returned to her after a tip from a man named Mick Sexton. To her surprise, the car had been modified with new red rims, detailing, and orange accents. Instead of being upset, Schoenig was amused and posted about it on Facebook, thanking the thieves for "pimping out" her vehicle. She is now having the car professionally cleaned due to a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana, and is also creating a smoothie in honor of the man who helped recover her car.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Manchester City players will lose £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League. The team's incentivised contracts, designed to meet financial fairplay requirements, are tied to their European performance. With their current fourth-place standing, City must secure a top-four finish to avoid missing out on a total of £12million in bonuses. The team's recent poor form, including a loss to Manchester United, has put their Champions League hopes in jeopardy, and manager Manuel Pellegrini has acknowledged that the season has "disintegrated" in recent months.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Manchester United's Under 18s team defeated Manchester City's Under 18s team 1-0 in a "mini-derby" match at Altrincham's Moss Lane stadium. The winning goal was scored by Callum Gribbin with a delightful free-kick. The match was played in front of nearly 1,000 spectators and featured a number of local players, with 10 of the 22 players on show being from Manchester. The result leaves United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League, while City have lost both matches in the end-of-season play-off series. The match showcased the skills and commitment of the young players, with several individuals impressing, including Gribbin, Marcus Rashford, and Marcus Wood.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Joe Hart, England's goalkeeper, has praised Italian goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon as a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th cap. Hart, who recently earned his 50th cap, expressed admiration for Buffon's longevity and skill at 37 years old. Hart, 10 years younger than Buffon, is inspired by the Italian veteran and hopes to continue learning and adding to his own cap total, aiming to keep playing well for both his club and country.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Chipotle, a Mexican restaurant chain, has partnered with the Postmates app to offer delivery services in 67 cities, targeting the $70 billion food delivery market. The service will come with a 9% service charge and delivery fees starting at $5, depending on distance and demand. This move is part of a larger trend, with other chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King also exploring delivery options. Notably, Chipotle has been a popular spot for presidential candidates, with both Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio recently spotted at their locations.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

The parents of the youngest Boston Marathon bombing victim, 8-year-old Martin Richard, are pleading to remove the death penalty for the convicted perpetrator, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev. They argue that pursuing the death penalty will lead to years of appeals, prolonging their family's pain and forcing their children to relive the traumatic event. Instead, they support a life sentence without parole and the waiver of Tsarnaev's appeal rights. The sentencing phase of the trial is set to begin, and the Richards hope to bring closure to the case and move towards a better future for themselves, Boston, and the country.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

A custom-built Boeing 747 jumbo jet has been converted into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire at a cost of £400million. The plane, which normally carries 600 passengers, has been tailored to fit the owner's specifications over a three-year period and features multiple lounges, bedrooms, an onboard restaurant, and a kitchen. The interior includes a large dining room, a conference room, an "aeroloft" with eight full beds, and a master bedroom with luxurious decorations. The plane can accommodate dozens of guests and is equipped with amenities similar to a luxury hotel, making it one of the most luxurious private planes ever built.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft from Cape Canaveral to the International Space Station. Although the launch was successful, the attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge was unsuccessful, with the rocket landing but tipping over. The mission aims to deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies to the space station, including research equipment and an espresso maker. After a five-week stay, the Dragon will return to Earth with over 3,000 pounds of cargo, splashing down in the Pacific Ocean. The ultimate goal of SpaceX is to master landing rockets at sea and eventually on land to reduce the cost of access to space by reusing rockets.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Priscilla Presley is collaborating with NBC's Today show to launch a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win a wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas. The winning couple, to be announced next Monday, will get married on April 23 at the chapel, located in the Westgate Hotel, with Priscilla serving as a witness. The prize includes a free wedding reception, hotel suite, airfares, and concert tickets. To enter, couples must submit a video or photos explaining why they deserve the prize. The chapel is part of a permanent Graceland exhibit and Priscilla has been involved in its design, emphasizing that it is a first-class and respectful tribute to Elvis, with no impersonators allowed.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League, despite being four points behind. This comes after Liverpool's 2-0 win over Newcastle United, where Raheem Sterling and Joe Allen scored. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season, equalling a record. Liverpool are looking to make up ground after recent poor results, and Henderson thinks that if they keep winning, they can put pressure on Manchester City, who have been faltering, having lost 4-2 to Manchester United.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in Serie A, thanks to a 25th-minute goal from Miralem Pjanic and several key saves from goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis. The win moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of city rivals Lazio and ended a seven-match winless streak at home. Napoli's winless streak was extended to five matches, and they remained in fifth place. The match was played under tight security due to past incidents between the two teams, but there were no reports of problems. Roma's victory was a significant boost, especially given the absence of injured captain Francesco Totti and fellow forward Gervinho.

Doncaster Rovers and Fleetwood Town played out a 0-0 draw in a League One match at the Keepmoat Stadium. Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a protest against high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. A newborn baby, Star, was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, shortly after birth. After an unsuccessful attempt to unblock her bile ducts, a liver transplant was the only option. Neither parent was a suitable match, but Star's maternal aunt, Shanell (her mother's twin sister), offered to donate part of her liver. The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb in Springfield, Illinois, are facing criticism and potential budget cuts. Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu healer, is one of thousands of West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) living in Indian Kashmir who have been denied citizenship rights for over 70 years. Despite never having visited Pakistan, they are unable to own property or vote in state elections, leaving them in abject poverty. With the recent success of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party, there is hope that their refugee status may finally be shed. Around 100,000 people are classified as WPRs, mostly living in the Jammu region, and are caught in a dispute over the territory with Pakistan. Successive governments have failed to grant them full rights due to fears of upsetting the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state. However, the newly-elected Bharatiya Janata Party has pledged to normalize the WPRs' status, giving them hope for a better future. If their hopes are dashed again, the community is ready to take matters into their own hands to fight for their rights.

* Open Garden's FireChat app allows users to chat without the need for the web or a mobile signal by creating a wireless mesh network.
* The app uses Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) to connect phones to each other, allowing messages to be sent to people in close proximity (up to 30 feet).
* However, there are limits to how far a message can travel in this way (around 200ft), which is where Greenstone, a small egg-shaped device, comes in.
* Greenstone acts as a beacon or booster to help messages move around wireless mesh networks more easily, extending the range of the network.
* The device is still under development, but it has the potential to enable resilient communication in areas with no connectivity, such as music festivals, protests, or hospitals.
* Greenstone can hold up to 1,000 recent messages and has a one-year battery life, and Open Garden is working with manufacturers to design and sell the device.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

* The University of Manchester has produced the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky.
* The map is the first in a series that will eventually allow a 3D view of dark matter across one eighth of the night sky.
* The goal of the Dark Energy Survey (DES) is to map 12.5% of the entire sky over five years, creating a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy.
* The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera and the Victor M. Blanco telescope, and shows clumps of dark matter across the sky.
* Dark matter makes up at least 80% of the matter in the known universe, but is invisible and can only be detected through its gravitational effects.
* The survey uses gravitational lensing to study the distortion of light around distant galaxies, allowing researchers to map the distribution of dark matter.
* The map will allow astronomers to study how galaxies formed in the universe and test current cosmological theories.
* The project has just completed its second year, and follow-up studies will reveal more about the interplay of mass and light in the universe.

They started in London and have covered almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) in 356 days, passing through 16 countries. They live on a tight budget of less than 3 euros per day, achieved by relying on free accommodation, such as camping (161 nights) and hosting websites (110 nights), and keeping food costs low by eating simple meals and occasionally dumpster diving. The couple documents their journey on their blog, "thecrazytravel", and expects to be on the road for several years.

A Texas couple, who got married in 2012, is suing James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing a racial slur on the bottom of photo booth snapshots from their wedding. The couple, who wishes to remain anonymous, claims they were not alerted to the photos until months after the celebration. Evans denies the allegations and refused to apologize, telling the couple to "sue" him. The couple is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Other possible factors include increased solo living and competing demands on time, leading to sex becoming a lower priority.

Professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, attributes this decline to the blurring of boundaries between public and private lives, with people constantly checking emails and being "too connected" to focus on their partners. This has led to a decrease in quality time spent with partners, causing sex to become a lower priority.

Tibetan Mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg, have experienced a dramatic decline in popularity in China. Just a year ago, they could command prices of up to £1.2 million, but now they are being sent to slaughterhouses and their meat is being used in cheap hotpots. The decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has stopped wealthy businessmen from giving the dogs as gifts to influence officials, and recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities. The breed's popularity was also affected by unscrupulous breeding practices, which led to a glut of poor-quality dogs, and the realization that Tibetan Mastiffs are not well-suited to city living. As a result, hundreds of the dogs are feared to be meeting a cruel fate, with many being stolen, sold to slaughterhouses, or abandoned.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The study, which compared the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds, found that children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight, with boys being more prone to weight gain. Repeated prescriptions before the age of two also raised the odds of being overweight. The researchers suggest that antibiotics may be contributing to the obesity epidemic by killing off gut bugs that normally feed on food, freeing up more food for the body and potentially increasing appetite. The study's lead author warns of the importance of judicious use of antibiotics in infancy, citing the potential role of antibiotics in the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident was caught on camera by a tourist, David Meadwell, who was recording the event. The guard lost his footing, slid sideways, and dropped his rifle, before quickly scrambling to his feet. The fall is believed to have been caused by the metal protectors on the soles of his boots. Despite the embarrassing moment, the guard's colleagues marched past as if nothing had happened. The incident occurred during a popular tourist event, where thousands gather to watch the changing of the guard outside Buckingham Palace.

LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake. The producers aim to add authenticity by consulting scholars in African and African-American history. The remake aims to introduce the story to a new generation, while also resonating with fans of the original, amidst a contemporary context of ongoing racial issues in the US.

He claims he was pinned to a chair, groped, and threatened after refusing to participate. Lawler reported the incident to palace officials at the time, but his complaint was ignored. He contacted the palace again last year after learning of investigations into historical child sex abuse cases, but his complaint was initially rebuffed. The complaint was eventually passed to Scotland Yard, and a retired royal aide was interviewed, denying involvement. The Royal Household has stated it will cooperate with the police investigation, which is ongoing.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt, which featured a black zigzag applique, was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film auctioned by Heritage Auctions. The dress was worn in several key scenes, including when Scarlett meets Rhett Butler and is attacked in the shanty town. The outfit has faded from its original slate blue-gray color to light gray due to age. The auction was part of a private collection amassed by James Tumblin, who collected over 300,000 pieces of memorabilia from the film. Other notable items sold at the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), a suit worn by Clark Gable ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000).

He suffered minor bumps and bruises, including a leg injury, and is in stable condition at the hospital. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family, citing eyewitness accounts that suggest the child was deliberately dangled over the railing. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu healer, is one of thousands of West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) living in Indian Kashmir who have been denied citizenship rights for over 70 years. Despite never having visited Pakistan, they are unable to own property or vote in state elections, leaving them in abject poverty. With the recent success of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party, there is hope that their refugee status may finally be shed. Around 100,000 people are classified as WPRs, mostly living in the Jammu region, and are caught in a dispute over the territory with Pakistan. Successive governments have failed to grant them full rights due to fears of upsetting the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state. However, the newly-elected Bharatiya Janata Party has pledged to normalize the WPRs' status, giving them hope for a better future. If their hopes are dashed again, the community is ready to take matters into their own hands to fight for their rights.

* Open Garden's FireChat app allows users to chat without the need for the web or a mobile signal by creating a wireless mesh network.
* The app uses Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) to connect phones to each other, allowing messages to be sent to people in close proximity (up to 30 feet).
* However, there are limits to how far a message can travel in this way (around 200ft), which is where Greenstone, a small egg-shaped device, comes in.
* Greenstone acts as a beacon or booster to help messages move around wireless mesh networks more easily, extending the range of the network.
* The device is still under development, but it has the potential to enable resilient communication in areas with no connectivity, such as music festivals, protests, or hospitals.
* Greenstone can hold up to 1,000 recent messages and has a one-year battery life, and Open Garden is working with manufacturers to design and sell the device.

* The University of Manchester has produced the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky.
* The map is the first in a series that will eventually allow a 3D view of dark matter across one eighth of the night sky.
* The goal of the Dark Energy Survey (DES) is to map 12.5% of the entire sky over five years, creating a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy.
* The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera and the Victor M. Blanco telescope, and shows clumps of dark matter across the sky.
* Dark matter makes up at least 80% of the matter in the known universe, but is invisible and can only be detected through its gravitational effects.
* The survey uses gravitational lensing to study the distortion of light around distant galaxies, allowing researchers to map the distribution of dark matter.
* The map will allow astronomers to study how galaxies formed in the universe and test current cosmological theories.
* The project has just completed its second year, and follow-up studies will reveal more about the interplay of mass and light in the universe.

Pablo Mandado (27) and Ilze Zebolde (31) are a couple who have embarked on an open-ended cycling journey around the world with no plans, agenda, or cause to fight for. They started in London and have covered almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) in 356 days, passing through 16 countries. They live on a tight budget of less than 3 euros per day, achieved by relying on free accommodation, such as camping (161 nights) and hosting websites (110 nights), and keeping food costs low by eating simple meals and occasionally dumpster diving. The couple documents their journey on their blog, "thecrazytravel", and expects to be on the road for several years.

A Texas couple, who got married in 2012, is suing James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing a racial slur on the bottom of photo booth snapshots from their wedding. England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback and is unsure when he will return to action. Brown pulled out of Harlequins' match against Saracens after experiencing a headache following England's game against France. He is determined not to rush back and risk an extended break, citing examples of other players like Johnny Sexton and George North who have suffered lengthy layoffs due to concussion. Brown credits increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by online modules, for helping him recognize his own symptoms and make informed decisions about his health. He is taking a staged approach to his recovery, starting with a 20-minute bike test, and is urging teammates to prioritize their health and not play on if they are showing symptoms of concussion.

Research suggests that smartphone use and the emergence of the internet may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of sex among couples. According to Professor David Spiegelhalter, a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. The decline is attributed to the blurring of boundaries between public and private lives, with people constantly checking emails and being "too connected" to focus on their partners. Other possible factors include increased solo living and competing demands on time, leading to sex becoming a lower priority.

Tibetan Mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg, have experienced a dramatic decline in popularity in China. Just a year ago, they could command prices of up to £1.2 million, but now they are being sent to slaughterhouses and their meat is being used in cheap hotpots. The decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has stopped wealthy businessmen from giving the dogs as gifts to influence officials, and recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities. The breed's popularity was also affected by unscrupulous breeding practices, which led to a glut of poor-quality dogs, and the realization that Tibetan Mastiffs are not well-suited to city living. As a result, hundreds of the dogs are feared to be meeting a cruel fate, with many being stolen, sold to slaughterhouses, or abandoned.

* A survey of 2,000 people identified the top 10 everyday emergencies, including not being able to sleep, losing keys, and running out of phone battery.
* Three prototype products were shortlisted: "Snooze" (an alarm clock that silences notifications), "Forget Me Lock" (a device that reassures you that your door is locked), and "Nipper" (the world's smallest mobile phone charger).
* The public can vote for their favorite product on Twitter using the #everydayfix hashtag, and the winner will be made into an actual product through a Kickstarter campaign.
* The competition is part of the Direct Line Everyday Fix design makeathon, which aims to create smart and simple solutions to real-life everyday emergencies.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The study, which compared the weight and height of over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds, found that children who had taken antibiotics as young babies were particularly likely to be overweight, with boys being more prone to weight gain. Repeated prescriptions before the age of two also raised the odds of being overweight. The researchers suggest that antibiotics may be contributing to the obesity epidemic by killing off gut bugs that normally feed on food, freeing up more food for the body and potentially increasing appetite. The study's lead author warns of the importance of judicious use of antibiotics in infancy, citing the potential role of antibiotics in the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic.

A Buckingham Palace guard slipped and fell on a manhole cover during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident was caught on camera by a tourist, David Meadwell, who was recording the event. The guard lost his footing, slid sideways, and dropped his rifle, before quickly scrambling to his feet. The fall is believed to have been caused by the metal protectors on the soles of his boots. Despite the embarrassing moment, the guard's colleagues marched past as if nothing had happened. The incident occurred during a popular tourist event, where thousands gather to watch the changing of the guard outside Buckingham Palace.

The 1977 miniseries "Roots" is being remade by A&E networks to air in 2016. The new version will be a simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History, and will draw more from Alex Haley's novel. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the remake. The producers aim to add authenticity by consulting scholars in African and African-American history. The remake aims to introduce the story to a new generation, while also resonating with fans of the original, amidst a contemporary context of ongoing racial issues in the US.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, 64, has alleged that palace aides at Clarence House tried to force him into an orgy in 1978. He claims he was pinned to a chair, groped, and threatened after refusing to participate. Lawler reported the incident to palace officials at the time, but his complaint was ignored. He contacted the palace again last year after learning of investigations into historical child sex abuse cases, but his complaint was initially rebuffed. The complaint was eventually passed to Scotland Yard, and a retired royal aide was interviewed, denying involvement. The Royal Household has stated it will cooperate with the police investigation, which is ongoing.

The video, which has been viewed over 1.7 million times on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood. They reveal that they spent two months trying to conceive and were surprised by the news. The video was made to share the news with loved ones living far away, but it unexpectedly went viral. The couple has shared a sonogram of their unborn child at the end of the video and may create another video after finding out the child's gender.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind sold for $137,000 at auction. The gray jacket and skirt, which featured a black zigzag applique, was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film auctioned by Heritage Auctions. The dress was worn in several key scenes, including when Scarlett meets Rhett Butler and is attacked in the shanty town. The outfit has faded from its original slate blue-gray color to light gray due to age. The auction was part of a private collection amassed by James Tumblin, who collected over 300,000 pieces of memorabilia from the film. Other notable items sold at the auction included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), a suit worn by Clark Gable ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000).

A 2-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after his parents dangled him over the edge. The boy slipped from his mother's grasp and fell 10-12ft into the pit, but was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived. He suffered minor bumps and bruises, including a leg injury, and is in stable condition at the hospital. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family, citing eyewitness accounts that suggest the child was deliberately dangled over the railing. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

After collapsing and being hospitalized, Laura received support from eating disorder organizations and began her recovery. * The University of Manchester has produced the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky.
* The map is the first in a series that will eventually allow a 3D view of dark matter across one eighth of the night sky.
* The goal of the Dark Energy Survey (DES) is to map 12.5% of the entire sky over five years, creating a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy.
* The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera and the Victor M. Blanco telescope, and shows clumps of dark matter across the sky.
* Dark matter makes up at least 80% of the matter in the known universe, but is invisible and can only be detected through its gravitational effects.
* The survey uses gravitational lensing to study the distortion of light around distant galaxies, allowing researchers to map the distribution of dark matter.
* The map will allow astronomers to study how galaxies formed in the universe and test current cosmological theories.
* The project has just completed its second year, and follow-up studies will reveal more about the interplay of mass and light in the universe.

Pablo Mandado (27) and Ilze Zebolde (31) are a couple who have embarked on an open-ended cycling journey around the world with no plans, agenda, or cause to fight for. They started in London and have covered almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) in 356 days, passing through 16 countries. They live on a tight budget of less than 3 euros per day, achieved by relying on free accommodation, such as camping (161 nights) and hosting websites (110 nights), and keeping food costs low by eating simple meals and occasionally dumpster diving. They have traveled through Western and Eastern Europe and have recently entered Asia, with plans to continue cycling across the continent and eventually reach the American continent. The couple documents their journey on their blog, "thecrazytravel", and expects to be on the road for several years.

A Texas couple, who got married in 2012, is suing James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing a racial slur on the bottom of photo booth snapshots from their wedding. The couple, who wishes to remain anonymous, claims they were not alerted to the photos until months after the celebration. Evans denies the allegations and refused to apologize, telling the couple to "sue" him. The couple is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. They are seeking an apology, at the very least, and have scheduled mediation, with a trial set for July if an agreement is not reached.

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback and is unsure when he will return to action. Brown pulled out of Harlequins' match against Saracens after experiencing a headache following England's game against France. He is determined not to rush back and risk an extended break, citing examples of other players like Johnny Sexton and George North who have suffered lengthy layoffs due to concussion. Brown credits increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by online modules, for helping him recognize his own symptoms and make informed decisions about his health. He is taking a staged approach to his recovery, starting with a 20-minute bike test, and is urging teammates to prioritize their health and not play on if they are showing symptoms of concussion.

Research suggests that smartphone use and the emergence of the internet may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of sex among couples. According to Professor David Spiegelhalter, a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. The decline is attributed to the blurring of boundaries between public and private lives, with people constantly checking emails and being "too connected" to focus on their partners. Other possible factors include increased solo living and competing demands on time, leading to sex becoming a lower priority.

Tibetan Mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg, have experienced a dramatic decline in popularity in China. Just a year ago, they could command prices of up to £1.2 million, but now they are being sent to slaughterhouses and their meat is being used in cheap hotpots. The decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has stopped wealthy businessmen from giving the dogs as gifts to influence officials, and recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities. The breed's popularity was also affected by unscrupulous breeding practices, which led to a glut of poor-quality dogs, and the realization that Tibetan Mastiffs are not well-suited to city living. As a result, hundreds of the dogs are feared to be meeting a cruel fate, with many being stolen, sold to slaughterhouses, or abandoned.

* The project has just completed its second year, and follow-up studies will reveal more about the interplay of mass and light in the universe.

A Texas couple, who got married in 2012, is suing James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, for allegedly printing a racial slur on the bottom of photo booth snapshots from their wedding. The couple, who wishes to remain anonymous, claims they were not alerted to the photos until months after the celebration. Evans denies the allegations and refused to apologize, telling the couple to "sue" him. The couple is suing under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, claiming negligence and breach of contract. They are seeking an apology, at the very least, and have scheduled mediation, with a trial set for July if an agreement is not reached.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

England full-back Mike Brown is adopting a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback and is unsure when he will return to action. Brown pulled out of Harlequins' match against Saracens after experiencing a headache following England's game against France. He is determined not to rush back and risk an extended break, citing examples of other players like Johnny Sexton and George North who have suffered lengthy layoffs due to concussion. Brown credits increased awareness of concussion symptoms, driven by online modules, for helping him recognize his own symptoms and make informed decisions about his health. He is taking a staged approach to his recovery, starting with a 20-minute bike test, and is urging teammates to prioritize their health and not play on if they are showing symptoms of concussion.

Research suggests that smartphone use and the emergence of the internet may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of sex among couples. According to Professor David Spiegelhalter, a typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. The decline is attributed to the blurring of boundaries between public and private lives, with people constantly checking emails and being "too connected" to focus on their partners. Other possible factors include increased solo living and competing demands on time, leading to sex becoming a lower priority.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

Tibetan Mastiffs, which can weigh up to 80 kg, have experienced a dramatic decline in popularity in China. Just a year ago, they could command prices of up to £1.2 million, but now they are being sent to slaughterhouses and their meat is being used in cheap hotpots. The decline is attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has stopped wealthy businessmen from giving the dogs as gifts to influence officials, and recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities. The breed's popularity was also affected by unscrupulous breeding practices, which led to a glut of poor-quality dogs, and the realization that Tibetan Mastiffs are not well-suited to city living. As a result, hundreds of the dogs are feared to be meeting a cruel fate, with many being stolen, sold to slaughterhouses, or abandoned.

A survey of 600 women in Paris found that every woman had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half of them experiencing it before the age of 18. The harassment ranged from insults and intimidation to sex attacks and rape. As a result, 6 out of 10 women feared being attacked on public transport, leading them to alter their daily lives to avoid confrontation. The survey led to calls for a campaign to address sexist and threatening behavior on buses and trains, with advocates emphasizing the need for women to feel safe in public spaces and for aggressors to be held accountable.

* A survey of 2,000 people identified the top 10 everyday emergencies, including not being able to sleep, losing keys, and running out of phone battery.
* Three prototype products were shortlisted: "Snooze" (an alarm clock that silences notifications), "Forget Me Lock" (a device that reassures you that your door is locked), and "Nipper" (the world's smallest mobile phone charger).
* The public can vote for their favorite product on Twitter using the #everydayfix hashtag, and the winner will be made into an actual product through a Kickstarter campaign.
* The competition is part of the Direct Line Everyday Fix design makeathon, which aims to create smart and simple solutions to real-life everyday emergencies.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, is facing a Ministry of Justice investigation after awarding £500,000 of taxpayers' money to a charity, Victims First Northumbria, of which she is a director. A 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, was brutally assaulted by a group of people, known as the "Tattoo Terrorists", led by Corry "Corey" Campbell, 21, in the basement of Campbell's mother's house in Philadelphia. The assault occurred in March 2014 and lasted for 42 hours, during which Valecce was beaten, tied to a chair, and forcibly tattooed with offensive images and words. The motivation behind the attack was Campbell's belief that Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles, and stolen from him. Three people, including Campbell, have been sentenced to prison, with Campbell receiving 20 years, while two others, David Harrison and Jennifer Pratt, are awaiting sentencing. Valecce suffered severe physical and emotional trauma, including broken bones and nightmares, and has since had the tattoos removed.
